noun.description: A large, heavy motor vehicle used for transporting goods, materials, or troops.
An undercarriage with four to six wheels pivoted beneath the end of a railroad car.
A wooden disk at the top of a ship's mast or flagstaff, with sheaves for signal halyards.

examples: the food was trucked to St. Petersburg

origin: Middle English (as a verb): probably from Old French, of unknown origin; compare with medieval Latin trocare.
phrases: we have no truck with that style of gutter journalism
The landlord has strict ideas about customer conduct and will likely have no truck with jugglers or squads of students handing out flyers.
I have no truck with anyone who uses violence, death or destruction to advance their position.
This means, among other things, having no truck with market research, PR companies, management consultants, etc.
The junior minister had only just been telling us that she was having no truck with those that would claim ignorance at this stage of the game.
